Discover Madagascar with us

About Madagascar Green Tours

Sustainable Tourism in Madagascar

At Madagascar Green Tours, we are dedicated to providing unforgettable travel experiences while preserving the unique biodiversity and cultural heritage of Madagascar. As a locally owned and operated tour company, we have deep roots in the communities we visit.

Our eco-friendly approach ensures that your adventure has a positive impact on both the environment and local communities. We work closely with conservation organizations and employ local guides who are passionate about sharing their knowledge and protecting their homeland.

  • Eco-friendly accommodations
  • Support for local communities
  • Conservation initiatives
  • Responsible wildlife viewing

Why Choose Us?

With over 15 years of experience, our team of expert guides will take you off the beaten path to discover the true essence of Madagascar. From the iconic Avenue of the Baobabs to the lush rainforests of Andasibe, we offer customized itineraries that cater to your interests and preferences.

Most Popular

Rainforest Adventure

Explore the lush rainforests of eastern Madagascar, home to countless species of lemurs, chameleons, and rare birds. Visit Andasibe-Mantadia National Park and experience the unique biodiversity.

7 days Max 8 people 4.9/5

Featured

Baobab & West Coast

Witness the iconic Avenue of the Baobabs at sunset and explore Madagascar's stunning western coastline. Visit Kirindy Reserve and the Tsingy de Bemaraha National Park.

10 days Max 6 people 4.8/5
View Details
Cultural

Cultural Immersion

Experience the rich cultural heritage of Madagascar with visits to traditional villages, artisan workshops, and local markets. Learn about the island's unique Malagasy traditions.

8 days Max 10 people 4.7/5

Frequently Asked Questions

The best time to visit Madagascar is during the dry season from April to October. This period offers pleasant temperatures and minimal rainfall, making it ideal for wildlife viewing and outdoor activities. The months of July and August are peak tourist season, so consider May, June, September, or October for fewer crowds but still excellent weather conditions.

Yes, most visitors need a visa to enter Madagascar. Tourist visas can be obtained upon arrival at international airports for stays up to 90 days. You'll need a valid passport with at least 6 months validity, a return ticket, and the visa fee (approximately €35). For the most current information, we recommend checking with your local Malagasy embassy or consulate before traveling.

Madagascar is home to an incredible array of unique wildlife. You can expect to see various species of lemurs (including the iconic ring-tailed lemur), chameleons, geckos, and over 100 species of birds found nowhere else on Earth. The island is also known for its unique baobab trees and diverse plant life. About 90% of Madagascar's wildlife is endemic, meaning it can't be found anywhere else in the world.
